topics.name: Strawberries
topics.body:
Strawberries aren't especially allergic foods, but as a fruit product they can contain unhealthy amounts of pesticides.
They're also considerably acidic, so they may cause skin irritants.
Source:
https://www.healthline.com/health/parenting/can-babies-eat-strawberries#Introducing-Strawberries

topics.name: Honey
topics.body:
Honey should not be fed to children under 12 months of age.
It contains small amounts of bacteria that can cause infant botulism.
If you've fed your child honey and you start to see symptoms of any kind developing, make an appointment with your doctor as soon as possible.
Source:
https://www.parents.com/baby/feeding/when-can-my-baby-eat-honey/.

topics.name: Speech
topics.body:
1-3 Months: Babies coo and cry
4-6 Months: More sounds but no clear words yet
6-9 Months: Babies will start to imitate tones, words, and general speech
12 Months: Words will start to appear, and by 2 years short sentences will start to arise.
 2-3 Years: Sentences can be 4-5 words, and can use words to identify objects.
Source:
https://www.pregnancybirthbaby.org.au/speech-development-in-children

topics.name: Walking & Crawling
topics.body:
Babies typically begin to crawl between 6-10 months. It's not uncommon for them to skip crawling altogether however.
It's a good idea to give babies incentives to move around (like placing toys just out of reach).
If your baby hasn't shown any progress in movement by 12 months, or drags one side while crawling, consult a pediatrician.
Source:
https://www.parents.com/baby/development/crawling/when-do-babies-crawl/

topics.name: Coordination
topics.body:
In the range of 3-6 months, babies will begin to grab and inspect items a lot more.
This increases as they age, as they subconciously develop their hand-eye coordination.
You can help develop these skills by letting them watch you while you perform tasks such as opening doors, clean surfaces, and eating.
Source:
https://otteroo.com/blog/baby-hand-eye-coordination/

topics.name: RSV
topics.body:
RSV (Respiratory Syncytial Virus) is a common, contagious virus that infects the respiratory tract of most children before their second birthday.
Most babies/young children won't experience much more then cold, but there is a chance that it can lead to a life-treatening problem like pneumonia or bronchiolitis.
RSV infections can cause cold-like symptoms, lasting 1-2 weeks but more serious symptoms like coughing with deeply colored mucus, dehydration, or problems with breathing can arise.
Call your doctor if these arise, and if they are very tired, breathing rapidly, or appear blue tinted on their fingers, call 911 or go to the ER immediately.
Source:
https://www.webmd.com/lung/rsv-in-babies

topics.name: Whooping Cough
topics.body:
Whooping Cough (Pertussis) can cause serious illness anyone, but especially in babies 1 year or younger.
The early symptoms of it are similar to the common cold, so only later symptoms can indicate an infection.
Symptoms at a later point include 'fits' of rapid coughing followed by a high-pitched 'whoop' sound, vomiting after coughing 'fits' and exhaustion after coughing 'fits'
Almost half of young children affected require hospitalization, so see a doctor as soon as discernible symptoms arise.
Source:
https://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/about/signs-symptoms.html

topics.name: Influenza
topics.body:
The flu (Influenza) just like RSV and Whooping Cough can display symptoms similar to a cold, the flu will onset much quicker then a cold however.
Any symptoms typical of the flu for adults will be the same for children.
It is imperative to visit a doctor when symptoms arise, as the flu can leave a child with a weakened immune system, especially for infants 6 months or younger.
Source:
https://www.webmd.com/children/your-baby-flu-faq#1

topics.name: Clothes
topics.body:
Keeping your child warm is extremely important. They aren't big enough yet to keep themselves warm (or know how to put on layers for themselves for that matter)
Onesies and jumpsuits are good for keeping them warm, as are jammies for bedtime.

topics.name: Toys
topics.body:
The best toys are ones that stimulate all of your babies senses.
Toys that stack together are also good for developing spacial awareness skills and basic mathematical understanding.

topics.name: Car Seats
topics.body:
Car seats have a limited time span of useability in a infants growth, but they are necessary in that time span.
It's always good to do your own research, but a recommendable selection would be the 'Chicco KeyFit 30' for most babies, and the 'Britax B-Safe 35' for a taller baby.
In any case, make sure the baby seat you buy has high crash ratings, since that will matter most in the worst situations.
Source:
https://www.nytimes.com/wirecutter/reviews/best-infant-car-seat/
